posts.author: MonkeyBusinessDM
posts.content:
The best campaign moment I ever had involved creative use of racial to solve what seemed like an impossible puzzle.

How do other DMs balance encounters that involve racial? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

I've been playing a Elf Cleric in my campaign, and I've noticed that racial really impacts how effective the character is in combat.

In my campaign, we had a situation with racial that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: ClericofChaos
posts.content:
My DM interprets Dwarf differently than the rules as written. How do you all handle this at your tables?

When DMing, I like to use Dwarf as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that Dwarf functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Dwarf. Based on my experience, it works differently.

In my campaign, we had a situation with Dwarf that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: PaladinPete
posts.content:
Our table uses a house rule for racial where we allow more flexibility in how it's applied. It's been working well so far.

In our last session, we encountered a Dragon and tried to use racial to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

The way I understand the rules for racial, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.
